Award.AwardTitle: Incomplete Preferences, Stochastic Choice, And Time And Risk Preferences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Economists who study how people make decisions have for many years started from the assumption that if an individual is faced with a choice between different alternatives, he or she can order the options from "most preferred" to "least preferred", as well as a number of other assumptions. However, a wide range of evidence now demonstrates that this theory is not able to explain how many people make certain specific kinds of decisions -- for example, the highest price someone is willing to pay for an object is often lower than the lowest price he or she is willing to accept to go without the same object. This award will fund the PI's continued efforts to develop alternative models of behavior based on the idea that individuals may not be able to compare all options; in other words, people have incomplete preferences. The PI plans to consider whether and how this theory can account for a range of document decision making behaviors. He also plans to conduct decision making experiments in a lab environment to test hypotheses drawn from the theory. The results will advance our scientific understanding of this kind of human decision-making, and could be useful to businesses and governments that need to predict how individuals will respond to new products and policies.

The research will focus on developing a model in which subjects' preferences may be incomplete, and using that model to analyze several specific biases in decision making: the gap between willingness to accept and willingness to pay, certainty effects, decision in stochastic environments, and intertemporal choice. The goal is to provide axiomatic characterizations of models in which subjects chose to randomize, including a special case where the desire to randomize comes from the agents' uncertainty about her own utility of consumption. The project will also include work on preferences on lotteries over consumption streams and will introduce an axiom that captures aversion to variability of consumption over time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding human decision-making, especially how people choose in the face of risk and uncertainty or for choices that have consequences over time, is crucial to understanding our behavior and how the economy works. It is also critical to designing optimal policy to predict the reactions to changes better.

This proposal has funded several projects that have deepened our understanding of decision-making in many areas.

 

The first set of results relate to “stochasticity” in decision-making. It is widely documented that humans often make different choices in the same situation, in a behavior that appears “random.” Decades of research have suggested that this randomness is due to fluctuations of preferences or mistakes. Instead, we propose that it may also be due to a desire to give stochastic answers—unsure of what to choose, people sometimes pick one option, sometimes the other. We provide a formal model of this behavior—published in the leading journal of Economics—and an experimental test of the prevalence of this desire to randomize, showing it is widespread and commonplace.

 

Another project studies how agents deal with risk over the timing of a reward: for example, whether subjects prefer a specific date for a reward or a risk lottery that pays the same reward earlier or later. We show in an experiment that agents are risk-averse in this case—they dislike randomness. This is, however, in contrast with leading models of decision-making. We then present a theoretical discussion on how to model such an attitude, showing it is incompatible with several assumptions that may appear appealing. The resulting paper has been published in the other leading journal in economics.

 

Other projects that originated by the two above are an experimental investigation of ambiguous information—how people react to information that may be true or misleading with unknown probabilities—and a theoretical study of aversion to disappointment in choices under risk and their connection to a notion of caution.
